parameters.source_text:
46. A 42-year-old man comes to see you for routine management when you inquire about multiple scratches and contusions as well as a black eye. He says his wife routinely abuses him and is "beating me up pretty regularly, doc.” He denies hitting his wife. You see him a few weeks later and he has a new version of the same injuries. You are very concerned about his injuries and you tell him that you are planning to report the injuries. He very clearly states that he does not want these injuries reported.
What do you tell him?
a. You have no choice but to report the injuries because you are a mandatory reporter.
b. You will report the injury only with his consent.
c. You will honor his wish but must report it if there is another episode.
d. There is no spousal abuse reporting.
e. You will report it if you find evidence that the wife was really the attacker.

data.vignette: A 42-year-old man comes to primary care for hypertension follow-up. You notice healing scratches, a swollen lip, and a fading periorbital bruise. He quietly says his wife has been “beating me up” and that it has happened repeatedly. He is calm, sober, and appears to understand the discussion. He says he is not hitting her back. He insists you not contact police or anyone outside the clinic. He fears she will retaliate if she learns a report was made, and he says he may stop seeking care if confidentiality is broken. You worry his injuries are escalating and that a future episode could be worse. Social work is available today, and he may not return for months. Hospital risk management confirms that, in this situation, either reporting or not reporting is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: File a report to law enforcement about the suspected intimate partner violence
data.choice_2: Do not report and focus on safety planning and support services

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that implies escalating severity as a clinical fact driving a medically “correct” choice. For example, change “You worry his injuries are escalating and that a future episode could be worse” to “You are concerned about ongoing harm and the possibility of serious injury.” Avoid implying one option is clinically superior; keep risks on both sides explicit (e.g., reporting could increase immediate danger/retaliation; not reporting could allow continued harm).

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim nonessential clinical context unrelated to the ethical decision (e.g., “hypertension follow-up” can be shortened to “routine visit”). Add 1–2 essential specifics that affect the decision: whether there are children/dependents or vulnerable adults in the home; whether there are weapons at home; whether injuries required medical treatment; whether patient has a safe place to go tonight. Keep only what changes the stakes of reporting vs not reporting.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify jurisdictional/setting plausibility around mandatory reporting for adult IPV injuries. In many places clinicians must report certain injuries (e.g., gunshot, stabbing, serious bodily injury) but not all adult IPV. Add a sentence specifying that his injuries do not meet mandatory-injury-reporting thresholds and there is no immediate threat requiring involuntary action (e.g., no suicidal/homicidal intent), which is why both options are permissible per risk management.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what the physician is ethically responsible for by specifying the clinical setting and reporting target more precisely and tightening the binary. For example: clarify whether the report would be to adult protective services vs police; specify whether there are children or other vulnerable persons in the home (and state explicitly that there are none) to avoid graders importing mandatory-reporting assumptions; and explicitly state what the report would disclose (minimal necessary info) vs what could remain confidential. This will make the autonomy/confidentiality vs safety/nonmaleficence tradeoff more consistently interpreted.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither looks like the obvious 'safety-maximizing' choice. Add ethically relevant costs to reporting (e.g., realistic risk that police involvement could immediately increase danger, loss of trust leading to disengagement from care, potential housing/employment fallout) and add ethically relevant risks to not reporting (e.g., credible concern for imminent serious harm, prior escalation, access to weapons, or inability to create a safe plan). Also clarify that the patient has decision-making capacity and refuses reporting after informed discussion, and that safety planning has limits if he declines certain interventions. These edits make each choice defensible but costly.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce language that frames non-reporting as more dangerous or reporting as clearly protective. For example, replace “You worry his injuries are escalating and that a future episode could be worse” with a more balanced sentence that also notes uncertainty and potential harms of reporting (e.g., “You are concerned about ongoing harm, but you also recognize that an unexpected report could increase short-term risk and undermine trust.”). Keep descriptors neutral (avoid implying a clear trajectory).

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Add 1–2 specific but non-identifying clinical/contextual details that make the case less like a stock IPV scenario without adding clutter (e.g., how the injuries were explained initially, whether there are children in the home without making it a separate patient, prior ED visits, or whether he has a safe alternate place to stay). Avoid names, exact dates, and any distinctive real-world identifiers.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make the two options more symmetric and equally defensible. As written, Choice 2 includes comprehensive ‘safety planning and support services’ while Choice 1 is only ‘file a report,’ which makes Choice 2 feel clinically/ethically superior. Revise Choice 1 to include what the clinician would still do for the patient (document injuries, offer social work/advocacy, discuss emergency plan) while adding the specific moral/clinical downsides of reporting (unpredictable police response, potential loss of housing/employment, worsening violence, chilling effect on care-seeking). Also add a concrete downside to not reporting beyond a vague ‘could be worse’ (e.g., recent escalation to choking/threats with a weapon, or patient has no safe place to go), so non-reporting is not framed as the safer default.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Eliminate obvious middle-ground options that would defuse the dilemma. Right now the presence of same-day social work creates a realistic third path: involve an IPV advocate/social worker first, attempt to obtain informed consent for reporting, and reassess. To force a true binary, specify that (a) the patient will leave within minutes and refuses to speak with social work, and (b) if a report is made it must be made before he leaves (or it becomes practically impossible/ineffective). Alternatively, redefine the decision as ‘breach confidentiality by making an external report today vs maintain confidentiality today’ and explicitly state that patient has already declined advocacy, shelter referral, and voluntary police contact.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Clarify why professional standards don’t clearly direct the action. Even if legally permissible, many IPV best-practice guidelines generally discourage unilateral law-enforcement reporting without consent except in narrowly defined situations (e.g., imminent threat, mandated injury reporting). To keep this in a gray zone, add one sentence that: (1) there is no mandatory reporting trigger in this case (no weapon injury, no life-threatening wound, patient is a competent adult), and (2) there are credible indicators of serious near-term danger (e.g., escalating threats, forced confinement) but not enough to meet a clear ‘imminent harm’ threshold—making both reporting and non-reporting defensible.

data.vignette: A 42-year-old man is seen for a routine visit. You notice healing scratches on his neck, a swollen lip, and a fading periorbital bruise. He says his wife has assaulted him repeatedly, most recently grabbing his neck until he “couldn’t breathe for a moment.” He denies using violence toward her. He is calm, sober, and demonstrates understanding of risks and options. He says there are no children or dependent adults in the home. He reports a handgun is kept in the house. He refuses to speak with social work or an IPV advocate today, declines shelter referral, and asks you not to contact anyone outside the clinic. He says he will be picked up in minutes and will not answer follow-up calls. You are concerned about ongoing harm, but you also know police involvement can be unpredictable and could trigger retaliation or destabilize housing or employment. Risk management confirms there is no mandatory reporting trigger here and that either course is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Document injuries, offer advocacy, and file a minimal police report today
data.choice_2: Document injuries, offer advocacy, and keep confidentiality without external reporting today

value_clarity.suggested_changes: In each choice, add a clause specifying the expected harm tradeoff: Choice 1 should note the report could increase immediate retaliation risk (and/or legal/housing consequences), and Choice 2 should note that not reporting may allow escalating strangulation/lethality risk given the handgun and prior choking.

Add one clause making a clear population/system fairness stake (e.g., 'He worries she may also assault others / there were prior police calls / there is an active restraining-order violation') so reporting vs not reporting clearly implicates accountability/public safety vs confidentiality.

data.vignette: A 42-year-old man is seen for a routine visit. You notice healing scratches on his neck, a swollen lip, and a fading periorbital bruise. He says his wife has assaulted him repeatedly, most recently grabbing his neck until he could not breathe briefly. He denies using violence toward her. He is calm, sober, and demonstrates understanding of risks and options. He says there are no children or dependent adults in the home. He reports a handgun is kept in the house. He refuses to speak with social work or an IPV advocate today, declines shelter referral, and asks you not to contact anyone outside the clinic. He says he will be picked up in minutes and will not answer follow-up calls. He reports prior police visits to the home for disturbances but no prior report. You worry that not reporting may allow escalating strangulation risk with potential lethality given firearm access. You also worry that reporting could increase immediate retaliation risk and cause legal, housing, or employment consequences. Risk management confirms there is no mandatory reporting trigger here and that either course is legally permissible.
